greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest number having exactly n partitions into distinct parts greater than 1, with each part divisible by the next.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
example: a(7) = 40, because A167865(40) = 7 and A167865(m) <> 7 for all m<40.  The 7 partitions of 40 into distinct parts greater than 1, with each part divisible by the next are: [40], [38,2], [36,4], [35,5], [32,8], [30,10], [24,12,4].
maple: a:= proc() local t, a, b;
if a(h) = -1 then a(h):= t fi
mathematica: a[n0_] := Module[{t = -1, a, b}, a[_] = -1; b[n_] := b[n] = If[n == 0, 1, Sum[b[(n - d)/d], {d, Divisors[n] ~Complement~ {1}}]]; While[a[n] == -1, t++; h = b[t]; If[a[h] == -1, a[h] = t]]; a[n0]];
Table[a[n], {n, 0, 100}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, May 21 2018, translated from Maple *)
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Mar 28 2011
